question.title: When does the (eclipse) debugger stop after clicking the suspend button?
question.body:
I have some code that I would like to be performant.

I rewrote that code to not allocate objects (as much as possible).

Now, when I run that code in Eclipse and I hit the suspend button the debugger always shows the same line of code. (A line without breakpoint.) (In all threads.)

(I would think, if my code is performant that the debugger would stop at random places in the code.)

As soon as I hit the suspend button, what does the debugger still do until it shows me the "currently" executing code?

How does the debugger work?

Does the debugger stops at the slowest line of code?

I don't know whether this is relevant but I use Graal.

question_comments.body: Maybe you get more variance when running with -XX:+DebugNonSafepoints but I never tried this. Generally, the answer must be, no, the location will not be random. Letting aside that the ability to stop the execution does not apply to every code location, having performant code does not imply equal chances for the execution to be at a particular point when trying to stop it.

To my understanding, when you hit the suspend button, the IDE tells the Java VM to stop via the Java Debug Wire Protocol (JDWP) and then the IDE uses also JDWP to get information like at which line the VM has stopped. It therefore depends on the Java VM used, not on the debugger of the IDE.
